questions.explanation: GDPR is the EU regulation that governs data protection and privacy for individuals.

options: Data that can identify a specific individual
questions.explanation: PII is any data that could potentially identify a specific individual (name, SSN, email, etc.).

options: Removing identifying information to prevent individual identification
questions.explanation: Anonymization removes or modifies PII so individuals cannot be identified from the data.

questions.prompt: What is the "right to be forgotten" under GDPR?
options: Right to request deletion of personal data
Right to delete your own files
questions.explanation: The right to erasure allows individuals to request deletion of their personal data under certain conditions.

options: Different privacy levels for different users
A technique that adds noise to data to protect individual privacy while preserving utility
questions.explanation: Differential privacy adds controlled randomness to data to prevent identification of individuals in datasets.

options: Systematic errors that create unfair outcomes for certain groups
questions.explanation: Algorithmic bias occurs when systems produce systematically prejudiced results due to biased training data or design.

questions.prompt: What is selection bias in data collection?
options: When the sample is not representative of the population
questions.explanation: Selection bias occurs when the data sample does not accurately represent the target population.

questions.prompt: What is fairness in machine learning?
options: Ensuring models do not discriminate against protected groups
questions.explanation: Fairness ensures ML models treat individuals and groups equitably without discrimination.

options: When a policy/model disproportionately affects a protected group
questions.explanation: Disparate impact occurs when a seemingly neutral practice has a disproportionately negative effect on a protected group.

questions.prompt: How can you mitigate bias in training data?
options: Ensure diverse, representative samples and audit for bias
questions.explanation: Bias mitigation requires diverse data collection, regular audits, and techniques to balance representation across groups.

options: AI systems whose decisions can be understood and interpreted by humans
AI that is easy to program
questions.explanation: XAI focuses on making AI decision-making processes transparent and interpretable to users and stakeholders.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of an ethics review board for AI projects?
options: Evaluate potential ethical risks and ensure responsible development
questions.explanation: Ethics review boards assess AI projects for potential harms, bias, privacy issues, and ensure ethical alignment.

questions.prompt: What is informed consent in data collection?
options: Users knowingly agree to data collection with understanding of how it will be used
questions.explanation: Informed consent requires clear communication about data collection, use, and obtaining voluntary agreement from individuals.

options: The degree to which humans can understand model predictions
questions.explanation: Interpretability refers to how easily humans can understand why a model made a particular prediction or decision.

questions.prompt: What is the dual-use dilemma in AI ethics?
options: Technology developed for beneficial purposes could be misused for harmful ones
questions.explanation: The dual-use dilemma addresses how beneficial technologies can potentially be repurposed for harmful applications.
